title: Bankers say 'please don't' as Trump renews call for lower rates
text:
New York | A trio of bankers warned that negative interest rates could hinder economic growth in the US even as President Donald Trump continues to urge policy makers to cut rates to less than zero.

Executives from Deutsche Bank and Morgan Stanley said Thursday (Friday AEDT) that negative rates haven't stimulated growth around the world -- comments they made just minutes before Trump tweeted that the Federal Reserve would be "derelict in its duties" if it doesn't lower interest rates further.

Companies and consumers in countries such as Germany are being paid to borrow money, Trump said.

"The negative-rate experiment, if you will, around the world has effectively not worked," Morgan Stanley chief financial officer Jon Pruzan said at a conference in New York hosted by the Financial Times. "So we're hoping we're not going to mimic a policy that hasn't worked."

Citizens Financial Group chief executive officer Bruce Van Saun said on the panel that while his bank is preparing for persistently low rates in the US, he doesn't believe policy makers will cut them to less than zero.
